content.description: Climb cracks and fractured edges up a small dihedral.  The crux comes as you pull over a small bulge about halfway, which is where the gear is a bit sparse as well.  At the top, peer over the knife edge and traverse right and down about 15 feet to the rap station.
content.protection: Carry a few hand and finger size pieces.  The rap station has slings with rap rings around a huge chockstone.
content.location: Hike up to the south face of the crag and find the small dihedral about 8 feet left of the rap line.  There is a good stance to rack up and belay from at the base of the route.

content.description: On the left edge of the South Face of Cartoon Crag is a sharp arete, climb it. There is no anchor on top so be prepared to downclimb or get creative.
content.protection: Little to none. Bring your go-for-it attitude.
content.location: On the far left edge of the South Face of Cartoon Crag, this is the obvious, sharp arete.

content.description: From behind pine tree, follow the obvious crack (overhung at start) that angles left and then jogs right near the top.
content.protection: Standard rack. Sling the block for an anchor with a double length sling and a backup with a cam.
content.location: This is on the left side of south face of Cartoon Crag, behind pine tree. The start is overhung for one move.

content.description:
Start as for

Goofy

, on the rightmost (north) crack system through the East face of Cartoon Crag.  As the crack splits at the bulge, stem on good holds out and right, then step back left into the left branch of the crack, avoiding the overhang this way. Continue up to the East Summit of the crag via system of cracks and a gully.
content.location:
This route starts as for

Goofy

, on the rightmost (north) crack system through the East face.

content.description: Climb through the bulging crack and follow the zig zagging crack (4th class) up to the rappel slings.  The crux is right off the ground and is well protected.  Careful of loose rock.
content.location: The route is on the east end of the south face.

content.description:
This is one of the better lines at Cartoon Crag, boasting reasonable protection and solid rock.

Start up just a few meters right of the left edge of Cartoon Crag's East Face.  The bulging base is overcome on positive and solid holds and gives way to a crack, and then a right-facing corner at mid-height. Past the corner, the cracks become intermittent, but the angle of the climb is lower and the grade easier.  Finish up into a bit of a summit gully and place a belay if you are leading/following.

To descend, scramble down into the notch South of the East summit and rap from a fixed station.
content.protection: A standard light rack of nuts and cams should give a leader reasonable protection along the way up.
content.location: This is the left-most route on the East face of Cartoon Crag, ascending a crack and corner system.

content.description: Climb through a bulge along a crack on the east face.  Then step right and follow the crack to the top.  At the top scramble to your left to find the rappel slings.  The climbing is okay, but be especially wary of loose rock.
content.location: This is the north crack on the east face.

content.description:
This is a fairly solid climb, but one that lacks the large holds and easy gear placements that others at this crag have.  The climb is more of a face climb than some of the others.  It is still relatively easy and a good solo, however.

Start out just down and right of the sole evergreen at the base of the South Face, climbing just to the right of a blocky overhang.  Pull up onto a solid slab of rock, staying left of the small, right-facing, flake system that is the climb '

Sneezy

' and climb up and very slightly left.  Reach the summit after passing a slight bulge a move below the top via a flake/shallow corner on its right side.
content.protection: A light standard rack should be able to get a few placements.
content.location:
This climb ascends the off-vertical South face up the center of the most prominent slab of stone there, starting just down and right of an evergreen tree.  See the crag

Info taken from Eldorado Canyon guidebook:  1. Donald Duck, 5.7 PG-13. 2. Lazy, 5.7 PG-13. 3. Doc, 5.3 PG-13. 4. Sneezy, 5.5 PG-13. 5. P.A. Pops Up again, 5.5 PG-13. 6. Sleep, 5.4. 7. Dopey, 5.4 PG-13. 8. Blind Man's View, 5.5 PG-13.  The climber on the top is at the rap rings.

.

content.description:
Just left of the zig zag crack that is

Sleepy

lies a short and shallow, right-facing corner. Steep but juggy rock will take you to the top.
content.protection: Protection is scarce, you may be able to fiddle in a few smaller nuts. There is no anchor at the top. Be prepared to downclimb or figure something else out.
content.location:
This is just a few feet left of the "

Sleepy

" crack system on the South face of Cartoon Crag.

content.description:
Probably the most interesting route on the crag, Donald Duck climbs a little steep terrain and feels even steeper than it is. Unlike other routes at the crag, this one is pretty secure and would protect well on lead.

Head up a crack through a steep spot off of the ground and pull right (steep)  heading up to a second bulge.  Pull over and left under a fin of rock on the arete and then up and right over it (steep) onto the right arete.  Ride this on easier terrain to the East Summit.

Descend via a rappel above the route '

Doc

' in the notch just to the West on the South Face or downclimb one of the easier routes.
content.location: This route is the right-most route on the South Face of Cartoon Crag.  It stays just left of the arete on cracks and flakes for 2/3 of its length before pulling onto the right side of the arete, on the East Side.

content.description: This climbs the obvious wide crack on the south face.  Many variations exist.  Going right where the wide crack narrows was a little easier.  Climbing the face to the left of the wide crack was more pleasant for me.
content.protection: Standard rack, large pro is not needed.
content.location: Walk around to the south face, and look for the fat crack.

content.description:
This is almost a bomb, but not quite.  It is not worth doing, but not worthy of a completely scathing review either.

Head up on good secure holds into the bulge, which is larger and harder than it appears.  Use some trickery to get through the top of the bulge, passing the lip on less than secure holds in awkward body positions. There is broken and slick rock and a bush to contend with at precisely that location. The climbing gets easier after pulling the bulge. Go left-side in.

This was the only route at the crag that I was unhappy soloing.  If you are going to do it, consider leading it with a rope for your safety.
content.location: This is the slightly chunky looking overhang on the left side of the East Face of Cartoon Crag.  A wide crack through a bulge is the defining feature and the crux climbing.
